item.title: World Health Body Endorses Use of Experimental Drugs Against Ebola Virus
item.description: The World Health Organization made its decision known as a Spanish priest became the first European known to have died in the Ebola outbreak.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: U.S. Signals a Willingness to Help New Iraqi Government
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said the U.S. would consider adding military and political support if Haider al-Abadi assumes the duties of prime minister.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: The Russian Tie We Can't Cut
item.description: For 25 years, U.S. funds have helped other nations safeguard nuclear material. Don't pinch pennies now.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM TOBEY, MATTHEW BUNN and NICKOLAS ROTH

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Preserving Biocultural Diversity
item.description: This dual extinction crisis is a golden opportunity for new directions in conservation.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID HARMON and JONATHAN LOH

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Matteo Renzi’s Red-Tape Problem
item.description: The Italian prime minister faces the task of hacking through the jungle of bureaucracy that is stifling business.
item.dc:creator: By BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Huge Russian Convoy Leaves Moscow for Ukraine, Bearing Aid
item.description: A convoy of about 280 trucks carrying humanitarian aid has left Moscow for southeastern Ukraine, Russian television and news agencies reported Tuesday.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Lens Blog: A Mountain of Uncertainty in Iraq
item.description: Adam Ferguson has been covering the refugee crisis in northern Iraq, where a persecuted minority has been trapped on a mountaintop.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yazidis refugees entered Iraq from Syria.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Dismissed Officials in China Don’t Always Disappear
item.description: An investigation by The Beijing News found that out of 85 officials who lost their positions over the past six years, more than one-third returned to public sector jobs.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Meng Xuenong in 2003, when he was mayor of Beijing.

item.title: ‘Systematic’ Killings in Egypt Are Tied to Leader, Group Says
item.description: Human Rights Watch is releasing a report on “widespread and systematic” killings of protesters.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Plea to Shun the Ivory Trade From Yao Ming
item.description: The obsession of some Chinese with possessing rare ornaments or ingredients of questionable medical benefit “is costing lives thousands of kilometers away,” the former basketball star Yao Ming said at a presentation of a documentary in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Yao Ming viewing the carcass of a poached elephant in Namunyak, northern Kenya.

item.title: Persecuted Yazidis Again Caught in Larger Struggle
item.description: A religious minority of about 500,000 people, neither Muslim nor Christian, is at the center of a growing humanitarian crisis in Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: World Briefing: Human Rights Council Plans to Investigate Gaza Conflict
item.description: The United Nations Human Rights Council has appointed three legal experts to an international commission to look into whether violations of international humanitarian and human rights law were committed during the conflict in Gaza.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Permanent Contraception Through Surgery Is Outlawed
item.description: Moving to allay the concerns of Iran’s supreme leader about the country’s declining fertility rate, Iranian lawmakers passed legislation that prohibits all surgical operations to permanently prevent pregnancy.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Kosovo: Suspects Rounded Up in Hunt for Mideast Fighters
item.description: The Kosovo police on Monday arrested at least 40 people in a major operation to round up suspects accused of fighting alongside extremists in Iraq and Syria.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Pentagon Says Airstrikes Have Slowed but Not Stopped Sunni Militants
item.description: Airstrikes have slowed the progress of Sunni militants laying siege to refugees on Mount Sinjar, but Pentagon officials also said that ISIS remained on the offense.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Members of the Yazidi minority, driven from their homes in northern Iraq by Sunni militants, headed toward the Syrian border, on the outskirts of Mount Sinjar.

item.title: At Heart of Ebola Outbreak, a Village Frozen by Fear and Death
item.description: More than 60 people have died from the virus in a tiny village in Sierra Leone, and now people there worry that a quarantine will cut off their food and supplies.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Tommy Trenchard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foday Ansumana Konneh, a villager in Njala Ngiema, Sierra Leone, said three of his wives and four of his children died of Ebola.

item.title: Iraqis Nominate Maliki Successor, Causing Standoff
item.description: The Iraqi president nominated the Shiite leader Haider al-Abadi to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has demanded to remain in power.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, ALISSA J. RUBIN and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Supporters of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki at a demonstration on Monday in Baghdad.

item.title: For 2 U.S. Presidents, Iraqi Leader Proved a Source of Frustration
item.description: Nuri Kamal al-Maliki rose from obscurity to power in part with American help, but U.S. leaders found him an often unconstructive ally who caused as many headaches as he solved.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Rome Journal: Standing Guard Over a Monarchy’s Tainted Legacy
item.description: The guards at the massive mausoleums commemorating Italy’s former monarchs struggle to preserve respect for those who once united the country.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Honor Guard to the Royal Tombs of the Pantheon stopping by the tomb of Umberto I, who was assassinated in 1900. Despite efforts to attract new members, the ranks of the Honor Guard have grown thin, and the tombs are often unattended.

item.title: Killings Rise in Karachi as Taliban Target Police
item.description: In the Pashtun slums of Karachi, Pakistan, militants have gunned down police officers, assaulted poorly defended police stations and dispatched suicide bombers to assassinate top police commanders.
item.dc:creator: By ZIA ur-REHMAN and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Kasparov Is Soundly Defeated in Bid to Lead Chess Federation
item.description: The former world chess champion lost an election in Norway in his effort to unseat the incumbent, Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov.
item.dc:creator: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN
item.media:credit: Rune Stoltz Bertinussen/NTB scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Garry Kasparov, the former chess world champion, answered questions from reporters in Norway after he lost the election for the presidency of the World Chess Federation.

item.title: Open Source: Iraqi Relief Flights Rescue Dozens, but Leave Thousands Behind
item.description: Images posted online Monday showed groups of Yazidis displaced from their homes in Iraq scrambling aboard military helicopters in the Sinjar mountains.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Russian Intervention in Ukraine Is Likely, NATO Says
item.description: As the Kremlin announced it had sent a convoy of humanitarian aid to Ukraine, NATO said there was a “high probability” of a Russian attack.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A stray rocket broke open the gate of a high-security prison in Donetsk, allowing more than 100 convicts to escape.

item.title: Obama Pledges Support for a New Iraqi Leader
item.description: President Obama said Monday that Iraq had taken a “promising step forward” with the choice of Haider al-Abadi to become prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Listening Post: A Rift in Worldviews Is Exposed as Clinton Faults Obama on Policy
item.description: In a blunt interview with The Atlantic, Hillary Clinton shattered an image of unity with the president, criticizing his “Don’t do stupid stuff” approach.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
